conclusion: Determine if the difference in displacement between objects A and B is continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
Object A is represented by the upper curve and Object B by the lower curve.
Displacement is the area under the v-t graph from the start to a given time.
For each object, the displacement can be represented by the area under their respective curves from 0 to t.
The difference in displacement between A and B at any time t is the difference in the areas under their curves up to that time.
Compare the areas under curve A and curve B from 0 to t1.
At the beginning, both objects start from the same velocity, so the areas are initially the same, and the displacement difference is zero.
Curve A is always above curve B, indicating that object A is always moving faster than object B.
The difference in displacement is continuously increasing as long as the area under curve A increases faster than the area under curve B.
Since A's curve is always above B's throughout the interval, the difference in displacement does not decrease or remain constant.
The difference in displacement between the two objects is continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
No, the difference in displacement between the two objects is not necessarily continuously increasing; it is continuously increasing in this specific scenario as shown by the areas under the curves.
